Detailed Description

An "abstract" representation of a file system entity identified by a pathname.

The pathname may be absolute (relative to the root directory of the file system) or relative to the current directory in which the program is running.

The actual file referenced by a File may or may not exist. It may also, despite the name File, be a directory or other non-regular file.

This class provides limited functionality for getting/setting file permissions, file type, and last modified time.

Although Java doesn't specify a character encoding for filenames, on gaia Java strings are converted to UTF-8 byte sequences when sending filenames to the operating system, and byte sequences returned by the operating system (from the various list methods) are converted to Java strings by decoding them as UTF-8 byte sequences.

The following example demonstrates how to use this File class.

 MyPage::onInit(Persistence* const savedInstanceState) {
           // new Content instance
     gaia::core::Context* context =  new Context(this);

     String fileName("file.txt");
     // Open a file which named file.txt.
     gaia::storage::File* file = context->getDirN(fileName,
                                       Context::MODE_WORLD_WRITEABLE);

     // Check this file whether it is a file or not.
     if (file->exists() && file->isFile()) {
         // Check this file whether it can be read and written or not.
         if (file->canRead() && file->canWrite()) {
             // Get the name of this file.
             base::String name = file->getName();
             // Get the length of this file in bytes.
             int64_t length = file->length();
             // Get the path of this file.
             String* str = new String(file->getPath());
             // Whether or not delete the file.
             bool del = file->deleteFile();
             // ...
         }
     }
 }

See the sample given above. There are many operations about File.

Member Function Documentation

bool gaia::storage::File::canExecute ( )

Tests whether or not this process is allowed to execute this file.

Note that this is a best-effort result; the only way to be certain is to actually attempt the operation.

Returns:
true if this file can be executed, false otherwise.

base::String gaia::storage::File::getCanonicalPath ( )

Returns the absolute path of this file with all references resolved.

An absolute path is one that begins at the root of the file system. The canonical path is one in which all references have been resolved. For the cases of '..' and '.', where the file system supports parent and working directory respectively, these are removed and replaced with a direct directory reference. If the file does not exist, getCanonicalPath() may not resolve any references and simply returns an absolute path name or throws an IOException.

Returns:
the canonical path of this file.
int64_t gaia::storage::File::getFreeSpace ( )

Returns the number of free bytes on the partition containing this path.

Returns:
the number of free bytes, or return 0 if this path does not exist.
base::String gaia::storage::File::getName ( )

Returns the name of the file or directory represented by this file.

Returns:
this file's name or an empty string if there is no name part in the file's path.
base::String gaia::storage::File::getParent ( )

Returns the pathname of the parent of this file.

This is the path up to but not including the last name. NULL is returned if there is no parent.

Returns:
this file's parent pathname or NULL.
File* gaia::storage::File::getParentFileN ( )

Returns a new file made from the pathname of the parent of this file.

This is the path up to but not including the last name. NULL is returned when there is no parent.

Returns:
a new file representing this file's parent or NULL.

bool gaia::storage::File::isAbsolute ( )

Indicates if this file's pathname is absolute.

Whether a pathname is absolute is platform specific. On gaia, absolute paths start with the character '/'.

Returns:
true if this file's pathname is absolute, false otherwise.
See also:

bool gaia::storage::File::isDirectory ( )

Indicates if this file represents a directory on the underlying file system.

Returns:
true if this file is a directory, false otherwise.
bool gaia::storage::File::isFile ( )

Indicates if this file represents a file on the underlying file system.

Returns:
true if this file is a file, false otherwise.
bool gaia::storage::File::isHidden ( )

Returns whether or not this file is a hidden file as defined by the operating system.

The notion of "hidden" is system-dependent. For Unix systems a file is considered hidden if its name starts with a ".". For Windows systems there is an explicit flag in the file system for this purpose.

Returns:
true if the file is hidden, false otherwise.
int64_t gaia::storage::File::lastModified ( )

Returns the time when this file was last modified, measured in milliseconds since January 1st, 1970, midnight.

Returns 0 if the file does not exist.

Returns:
the time when this file was last modified.
int64_t gaia::storage::File::length ( )

Returns the length of this file in bytes.

Returns 0 if the file does not exist. The result for a directory is not defined.

Returns:
the number of bytes in this file.
base::StringArray gaia::storage::File::list ( )

Returns an array of strings with the file names in the directory represented by this file.

The result is empty array if this file is not a directory.

The entries . and .. representing the current and parent directory are not returned as part of the list.

Returns:
an array of strings with file names or empty array.
See also:
isDirectory
base::Array<File*> gaia::storage::File::listFilesN ( )

Returns an array of files contained in the directory represented by this file.

The result is empty array if this file is not a directory. The paths of the files in the array are absolute if the path of this file is absolute, they are relative otherwise.

Make sure to call cleanFileArray when you no longer need these files, or you can delete these files by yourself.

Returns:
an array of files or empty array.
See also:
list
isDirectory
cleanFileArray
static base::Array<File*> gaia::storage::File::listRootsN ( ) [static]

Lists the file system roots.

The Java platform may support zero or more file systems, each with its own platform-dependent root. Further, the canonical pathname of any file on the system will always begin with one of the returned file system roots.

Make sure to call cleanFileArray when you no longer need these files, or you can delete these files by yourself.

Returns:
the array of file system roots.
See also:
cleanFileArray
bool gaia::storage::File::mkdir ( )

Creates the directory named by the trailing filename of this file.

Does not create the complete path required to create this directory.

Returns:
true if the directory has been created, false otherwise.
See also:
mkdirs
bool gaia::storage::File::mkdirs ( )

Creates the directory named by the trailing filename of this file, including the complete directory path required to create this directory.

Returns:
true if the necessary directories have been created, false if the target directory already exists or one of the directories can not be created.

bool gaia::storage::File::setExecutable ( bool  executable)

Manipulates the execute permissions for the abstract path designated by this file.

Parameters:
executableTo allow execute permission if true, otherwise disallow
Returns:
true if and only if the operation succeeded. If the user does not have permission to change the access permissions of this abstract pathname the operation will fail. If the underlying file system does not support execute permission and the value of executable is false, this operation will fail.
bool gaia::storage::File::setLastModified ( int64_t  time)

Sets the time this file was last modified, measured in milliseconds since January 1st, 1970, midnight.

Parameters:
timethe last modification time for this file.
Returns:
true if the operation is successful, false otherwise.
bool gaia::storage::File::setReadable ( bool  readable,
bool  ownerOnly 
)

Manipulates the read permissions for the abstract path designated by this file.

Parameters:
readableTo allow read permission if true, otherwise disallow
ownerOnlyTo manipulate read permission only for owner if true, otherwise for everyone. The manipulation will apply to everyone regardless of this value if the underlying system does not distinguish owner and other users.
Returns:
true if and only if the operation succeeded. If the user does not have permission to change the access permissions of this abstract pathname the operation will fail. If the underlying file system does not support read permission and the value of readable is false, this operation will fail.
bool gaia::storage::File::setReadOnly ( )

Marks this file or directory to be read-only as defined by the operating system.

Returns:
true if the operation is successful, false otherwise.

bool  ownerOnly 
)

Parameters:
writableTo allow write permission if true, otherwise disallow
ownerOnlyTo manipulate write permission only for owner if true, otherwise for everyone. The manipulation will apply to everyone regardless of this value if the underlying system does not distinguish owner and other users.
Returns:
true if and only if the operation succeeded. If the user does not have permission to change the access permissions of this abstract pathname the operation will fail.
